dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so you know, the tech world, it's always full of drama, but lately, the dynamic between Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey has been, uh, particularly wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely! It's like watching a really confusing, high-stakes tennis match where they keep switching sides. One minute they're praising each other, the next, it's a thinly veiled jab.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely! It's like watching a really confusing, high-stakes tennis match where they keep switching sides. One minute they're praising each other, the next, it's a thinly veiled jab.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I mean, Zuck, in a move that honestly felt a bit ironic given his past, initially pushed for really strict real-identity rules on Facebook, right? Like, mirroring his old social network building days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I mean, Zuck, in a move that honestly felt a bit ironic given his past, initially pushed for really strict real-identity rules on Facebook, right? Like, mirroring his old social network building days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, Zuckerberg built a social network employing strict rules about using your real identity, while Dorsey and Twitter championed anonymity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then, [interrupts] almost immediately, Dorsey and Twitter, who were always about *requiring* real ID verification, suddenly did this complete volte-face. They championed unrestricted anonymity. It was, like, a total 180.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then, almost immediately, Dorsey and Twitter, who were always about requiring real I D verification, suddenly did this complete volte-face. They championed unrestricted anonymity. It was, like, a total one hundred eighty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, Zuckerberg built a social network employing strict rules about using your real identity, while Dorsey and Twitter championed anonymity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And this was after, what, a month of intense pressure from Zuckerberg advocating for more political advertising and "free speech" on his platform. Then Twitter just drops this bomb: they're embracing political ads.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And this was after, what, a month of intense pressure from Zuckerberg advocating for more political advertising and free speech on his platform. Then Twitter just drops this bomb: they're embracing political ads.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, their whole thing was, uh, "political message reach should be bought, not earned." Which, you know, came out well before Facebook's earnings call, and even before that leaked audio from a Facebook meeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, their whole thing was, uh, political message reach should be bought, not earned. Which, you know, came out well before Facebook's earnings call, and even before that leaked audio from a Facebook meeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's all about free expression, Dorsey declared in a series of tweets. But then he also said, "This is about paying for reach."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all about free expression, Dorsey declared in a series of tweets. But then he also said, This is about paying for reach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt about free expression, Dorsey said in a series of tweets. This is about paying for reach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And here's where it gets even weirder: Dorsey’s comments actually praised how Zuckerberg defended Facebook's political ads policy, which, ironically, *bans* politicians from making false claims.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And here's where it gets even weirder: Dorsey's comments actually praised how Zuckerberg defended Facebook's political ads policy, which, ironically, bans politicians from making false claims.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorseys comments took aim at how Zuckerberg has defended Facebooks political ads policy, which allows politicians and political candidates to make false claims in advertisements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, while Zuckerberg himself was out there positioning Facebook as "anti-American-values-based," limiting free speech. He even said, "Most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% false."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, while Zuckerberg himself was out there positioning Facebook as anti-American-values-based, limiting free speech. He even said, Most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be one hundred percent false.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zuckerberg has positioned Facebook as an American-values-based company that champions free speech by allowing anyone to publish any of their thoughts, as long as they dont threaten physical harm. ... I dont think most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% true, Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But then Dorsey, um, he added a much less veiled shot, noting it would be credible to say, "We're working hard to spread misleading info using gaming systems, buuut if someone pays us to target... they can say whatever they want!" And then he added a wink!

Then, he added a wink.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A wink! So much for praising Zuckerberg's policy, huh? It's like this bizarre public collaboration, where they're both, like, ignoring massive disinformation campaigns ahead of the election.

dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it’s not even consistent. I mean, earlier, at the Twitter News Summit, Dorsey actually criticized Zuckerberg’s free speech argument. He said it had a "major gap and flaw" and lacked "genuineness."

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then, like, when asked if he'd join Facebook's Libra project, Dorsey's answer was just, "Hell, yes."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then, like, when asked if he'd join Facebook's Libra project, Dorsey's answer was just, Hell, yes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And then, after the leaked Facebook audio, Zuckerberg turned around and praised Twitter! He said they face the same issues and their safety investment is "bigger than the whole revenue of our company." It's just... bewildering.
